Stone-Weierstrass

Let μ\muμ be a real-valued Borel measure on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1] such that

∫011x+t dμ(t)=0for all x>1.\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x + t} \,\diff\mu\p{t} = 0 \quad\text{for all } x > 1.∫01​x+t1​dμ(t)=0for all x>1.

Show that μ=0\mu = 0μ=0.
Solution.

By Riesz representation, we see μ∈(C([0,1]))∗\mu \in \p{C\p{\br{0,1}}}^*μ∈(C([0,1]))∗, so it suffices to show that ∫01f(t) dμ(t)=0\int_0^1 f\p{t} \,\diff\mu\p{t} = 0∫01​f(t)dμ(t)=0 for all f∈C([0,1])f \in C\p{\br{0,1}}f∈C([0,1]).

First, observe that by the mean value theorem, if ∣h∣<x−1\abs{h} < x - 1∣h∣<x−1, then there exists ξ∈[1,x]\xi \in \br{1, x}ξ∈[1,x] so that

∣1h(1((x+h)+t)n−1(x+t)n)∣=∣n(ξ+t)n+1∣≤n.\abs{\frac{1}{h}\p{\frac{1}{\p{\p{x + h} + t}^n} - \frac{1}{\p{x + t}^n}}} = \abs{\frac{n}{\p{\xi + t}^{n+1}}} \leq n.∣∣​h1​(((x+h)+t)n1​−(x+t)n1​)∣∣​=∣∣​(ξ+t)n+1n​∣∣​≤n.

Since μ([0,1])∈R\mu\p{\br{0,1}} \in \Rμ([0,1])∈R, in particular μ\muμ is finite, and so constants are in L1(μ)L^1\p{\mu}L1(μ). By dominated convergence,

0=lim⁡h→01h∫011((x+h)+t)n−1(x+t)n dμ(t)=−n∫011(x+t)n+1 dμ(t).0 = \lim_{h\to0} \frac{1}{h} \int_0^1 \frac{1}{\p{\p{x + h} + t}^n} - \frac{1}{\p{x + t}^n} \,\diff\mu\p{t} = -n \int_0^1 \frac{1}{\p{x + t}^{n+1}} \,\diff\mu\p{t}.0=h→0lim​h1​∫01​((x+h)+t)n1​−(x+t)n1​dμ(t)=−n∫01​(x+t)n+11​dμ(t).

Indeed, this is true for n=1n = 1n=1 by assumption, and it follows for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N by induction. Hence, we have shown that

∫011(x+t)n dμ(t)=0\int_0^1 \frac{1}{\p{x + t}^n} \,\diff\mu\p{t} = 0∫01​(x+t)n1​dμ(t)=0

for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Now let AAA be the set of all finite R\RR-linear combinations of 1(2+t)n\frac{1}{\p{2 + t}^n}(2+t)n1​ for n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. It's clear that AAA is a subalgebra of C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]), that it vanishes nowhere, and that it separates points (e.g., 12+t\frac{1}{2 + t}2+t1​ does both). By Stone-Weierstrass, we see that AAA is dense in C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]). Since μ\muμ is 000 on a dense subset of C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]), it follows that μ\muμ is 000 on all of C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]), and so μ=0\mu = 0μ=0, which was what we wanted to show.
